com.week8.heap

Class Heap<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.week8.heap.Heap<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class Heap<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    A Heap is a binary tree with h levels, which is fully loaded on the levels 0,1...h-2; every child on the last level h-1 is set from left to right. The elements are either ordered by a Comparator or by there natural ordering, given by their implementation of java.util.Comparable. In order to avoid a ClassCastException the user must only insert java.util.Comparable Elements or define a Comparator. Given this order, every element in a parent node is smaller than the elements in both child nodes.

    The first element of a Heap is always the smallest element. It can be deleted by deleteFirst() or received by getFirst(). A new element can be inserted by #insert(E).

    A Heap is unbound an will automatically grow when inserting new elements.

    See Also:

    • Constructor Detail

      • Heap

        public Heap()
        Creates a new empty heap. E must implement java.util.Comparable in order to avoid a ClassCastException.

      • Heap

        public Heap(java.util.Comparator<? super E> comparator)
        Creates a new empty Heap. The elements inserted will be compared using the given Comparator. If comparator is null E must implement java.util.Comparable in order to avoid a ClassCastException.
        Parameters:
        comparator - a Comparator to compare the inserted elements

      • insert

        public void insert(E e)
        Inserts e into this Heap. May throw a ClassCastException if this Heap has been initialized without a Comparator and E does not implement java.util.Comparable. Throws a NullPointerException if e is null.
        Parameters:
        e - element to be inserted
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if e is null
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if no this Heap was not initialized with a Comparator an E does not implement Comparable

      • getFirst

        public E getFirst()
        Returns the first, or smallest element in this Heap.
        Returns:
        the first element in this Heap or null

      • size

        public int size()
        Returns the size of this Heap.
        Returns:
        number of elements hold by this Heap

      • empty

        public boolean empty()
        Returns if this Heap is empty or not
        Returns:
        true if this Heap is empty

      • deleteFirst

        public E deleteFirst()
        Deletes the first, or smallest element in this Heap and returns. Puts the last element of this Heap to the root and reorganizes this Heap such that the Heap axioms are fulfilled. Throws Exception if this Heap is empty.
        Returns:
        the first element in this Heap, which has been deleted
